task: Create a new file named hello.py.
Write a program that prints: Hello, world! (exactly)
Run it from the terminal: python hello.py
(Optional) Print 3 different lines.

docs_links_append.label: YouTube: Install + run your first Python program (Corey Schafer)

task: Create a file named variables.py.
Make 2 variables (for example: name and age).
Print both values in one sentence.
Change one variable and print again.
(Optional) Add a third variable (favorite_food, favorite_game, etc.).

docs_links_append.label: YouTube: Variables & Data Types (Tech With Tim)

example_run: My name is Alex and I am 12 years old.
Now my name is Alex and I am 13 years old.

text: This is one simple example using f-strings.
code: print(f'My name is {name} and I am {age} years old.')
print(f'Now my name is {name} and I am {age} years old.')

task: Create a file named echo.py.
Ask the user for their name using input(...).
Print a greeting using the user's input.
Ask for a second value (favorite color / game / animal) and echo it back.
(Optional) Format the output nicely (newlines, punctuation).

docs_links_append.label: YouTube: Basic Operators & Input (Tech With Tim)

task: Create a file named parse_numbers.py.
Read one whole number (int) from input and print it + 1.
Read one decimal number (float) and print it * 2.
Print the type(...) of both parsed values.
(Optional) Handle bad input by printing a friendly message.
Create a file named calculator.py.
Read two numbers (use float) from input.
Print the results of: +, -, *, /.
If the second number is 0, don’t crash on division (print a message).
(Optional) Ask for the operator (+ - * /) and only do that one.

docs_links_append.label: YouTube: Basic Operators & Input (Tech With Tim)

task: Create a file named even_odd.py.
Read an integer n.
If n is even, print: even. Otherwise print: odd.
Test with: 0, 1, 2, -3.
(Optional) Also print whether n is positive/negative/zero.

docs_links_append.label: YouTube: IF / ELIF / ELSE (Tech With Tim)

task: Create a file named max3.py.
Read three integers a, b, c.
Print the largest value.
Test with a tie case (like 5, 5, 1).
(Optional) Print the smallest value too.

docs_links_append.label: YouTube: IF / ELIF / ELSE (Tech With Tim)

task: Create a file named count_to_n.py.
Read an integer N.
Print the numbers 1..N (one per line).
If `N <= 0`, print a message instead of looping.
(Optional) Also print N..1 (countdown).
Create a file named fizzbuzz.py.
For numbers 1..N:
- Print Fizz if divisible by 3
- Print Buzz if divisible by 5
- Print FizzBuzz if divisible by both
- Otherwise print the number
(Optional) Let the user choose N; default to 100.

text: Keep it simple. This is one valid way; many others are fine.

task: Create a file named guess.py.
Pick a secret number between 1 and 100.
Loop: ask for a guess until they get it right.
After each guess, print: too high / too low.
When correct, print how many guesses it took.
(Optional) Add an attempt limit (like 10 tries).
hints: Use a while True loop, break when correct.
Keep a counter guesses += 1 each loop.
